question: Question_06_(a)
statement:
Prove that $1+3+5+ \ldots +(2n-1)$ is a perfect square for all n â
\textbf{N}. (An integer \emph{m} is a perfect square if \emph{m} =
\emph{k}\textsuperscript{2} for some integer \emph{k}.)
sols:
We start our induction at \emph{n} = 1. In that case we have that
2\emph{n} - 1 = 1 and so the sum is just 1 alone which is a perfect
square.

We can check \emph{n} = 2 if we want as well, in that case 2\emph{n} - 1
= 4 - 1 = 3 and so the sum is 1 + 3 = 4 which is the square of 2.

For \emph{n} = 3 we have that 1 + 3 + 5 = 9 which is the square of 3; we
now see something which seems to be a pattern, that is for \emph{n} =
\emph{k} the sum will end up being the square of the number \emph{k}.
And so we conjecture that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
1+3+5+\ldots + (2n-1) = n^2\end{align*}

We have proved above that this is true for \emph{n} = 1, 2 and 3. We
will use induction to prove that is holds for all values of \emph{n}.
Since we have the first step(s) done, we now assume that the conjecture
holds for \emph{n} = \emph{k} and we will show that it still holds for
\emph{n} = \emph{k}+1. Indeed

\begin{align*}
\underbrace{1 + 3 +5 +\ldots + (2k-1)}_{=k^2} + (2(k+1)-1) &= k^2 + (2k+2-1)\\
&= k^2 + 2k + 1\\
&=(k+1)^2\end{align*}

This shows that our conjecture is true for \emph{n} = \emph{k}+1 and
thus concludes our proof.

\emph{The following proof is not valid for the purpose of this exam
question since it doesn't use induction, but it is of the level of this
course, so we add it here for completeness.}

Consider playing with square pieces of paper, or colouring squares in a
lined piece of paper. If you look at a \emph{n} by \emph{n} square, it
is made of \emph{n}\textsuperscript{2} squares. The next square you can
built, which will have now \emph{n}+1 squares on each side will contain
(\emph{n}+1)\textsuperscript{2} squares, but how many squares were added
to it? Well you need to add a layer on say the right side, so \emph{n}
additional squares and also a layer on the top side, so another \emph{n}
additional squares and now you are also missing one square at the top
right corner, so yet another square. In total, to go from the square
with \emph{n} little squares on the side to the next one with \emph{n}+1
squares on each side you need to add 2\emph{n}+1 squares.

So if we start with 1 square, we need to add 3 squares to get a 2 by 2
squares and we need to add 5 squares to that to get a 3 by 3 square and
we need to add 7 squares to get a 4 by 4 square and hence if we sum
$1+3+5+ \ldots + (2n-1)$ squares we will get a \emph{n} by \emph{n}
square. Which is exactly what we wanted to show.

\emph{The following proof is not valid for the purpose of this exam
question since it doesn't use induction, but it is of the level of this
course, so we add it here for completeness.}

Another proof can be obtained by simply playing with the formula that
sums consecutive integers, that is

\begin{align*}1+2+3+4+5+6+\dots + k = \sum_{i=1}^k i = \frac{k(k+1)}{2}\end{align*}

And we just use the fact that

\begin{align*}
1+3+5+\dots+(2n-1) &= \left( 1+2+3+ \ldots +(2n-1) + (2n) \right) \\
&\quad - (2 + 4 + 6 + \ldots + (2n))\end{align*} Or if we use sum notations

\begin{align*}\sum_{i=1}^n (2i-1) = \sum_{i=1}^{2n} i - \sum_{i=1}^n 2i\end{align*} Now using
the formula above we obtain that

\begin{align*}\sum_{i=1}^{2n} i = \frac{2n(2n+1)}{2} = n(2n+1) = 2n^2+n\end{align*} and

\begin{align*}\sum_{i=1}^n 2i = 2\sum_{i=1}^n i = 2\frac{n(n+1)}{2} = n(n+1) = n^2+n\end{align*}
And so

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
1+3+5+\dots+(2n-1) = (2n^2+n) - (n^2+n)=n^2\end{align*} which proves that it is a
perfect square.

(2\emph{n}-1) and prove that formula holds by induction.
